userFeedbackSnapshot.point: Users appreciate the all-in-one workflow that handles script generation and asset sourcing
Access to premium stock libraries is seen as a time-saver compared to managing separate subscriptions
The learning curve is gentle for those new to video creation
Credits can run out quickly with heavy iteration and regeneration
Watermark on free plan limits professional publishing
Export quality depends on plan tier, which can be confusing

commonIssues.point: Edits/regenerations may burn minutes/credits faster than expected
Export can stall on longer videos / browser reliability issues
Stock relevance can be generic/off-topic and require manual swaps

faqs.q: Is InVideo AI completely free to use?
faqs.a: Yes—you can try it on the free plan, but exports are watermarked and usage is capped. Treat it as a workflow trial, not a plan for publishing consistently.

faqs.q: Do edits consume credits in InVideo?
faqs.a: Often, yes—users report that regenerating scenes or making certain changes can deduct minutes/credits, not just the first generation. If you iterate heavily, track usage closely and finalize your script before regenerating.

faqs.q: Can I monetize InVideo AI videos on YouTube?
faqs.a: Usually, monetization is safest on paid tiers where commercial terms are clearer. For client work or resale, double-check your plan's licensing and the stock asset terms before publishing.

faqs.q: Can I use InVideo stock footage commercially?
faqs.a: It depends on your plan and the asset source (premium libraries are typically tiered and capped). If you're publishing ads or client work, confirm the plan's commercial/resale coverage in the official terms/help docs.

faqs.q: How to remove InVideo watermark without paying?
faqs.a: You can't remove the watermark on the free plan—watermark removal is a paid feature. If you need publishable exports, you'll need a paid tier or a tool with a no-watermark free policy.

faqs.q: What browsers work best with InVideo?
faqs.a: Chrome tends to be the safest choice for editing and exports. Some users report playback/export issues on Firefox, especially on longer projects.

faqs.q: Why do my exports fail at 99% completion?
faqs.a: This is commonly reported with longer timelines or heavy assets. Try exporting in Chrome, splitting long videos into shorter segments, and reducing effects/overlays before re-exporting.
Exported videos generally remain usable, but your editing access and monthly credits can change after cancellation. If you're mid-project, export final versions before your billing period ends.
